content.description: This has hard moves off the deck around a knifeblade for pro. It is awesome, black granite, mixed sport climbing.
content.protection:
In the book, it says "the only sport route on the cliff". Not true at all, you could get messed up if you didn't bring gear, especially over the roof!

5 bolts, 1 KB, 0.75 and 0.5 cams, and a blue Alien.
content.location:
20' right of "

Cardo's

", look for a knifeblade about 10-12' up by an undercling.

content.description: Peruvian Flake is a fun wondering route that follows the contours of a flake/dihedral up the center of a clean face.  Where the flake ends, move left across a thin face and then follow flaring cracks to the top.
content.protection: Standard rack up to a 2" or 3" piece with one fixed pin.  Two bolt anchor at the top.
content.location:
This route starts about 10' left of

Dean's Day Off

at an obvious dihedral.

content.description:
Start in the right-facing corner, black water streak.  Stem and jam your way up a slot, easily avoided to the left.  Continue up the the final "headwall" and choose your finish.  Easiest out left, flaring straight up or move right and finish up on the finger crack of

Peruvian Flake

(a move of 9+/10-).

There are two Metolius rap hangers just above the lip of the finish, the right one spins and will need replacing sooner than later.  You do not see these hangers until you top out.

There is now an anchor at the top of

Peruvian Flake

, visible from the ground.

Now Landslide and

Peruvian

have independent anchors.
content.protection:
Red C3 to blue Camalot, single set and a couple of medium nuts, some runners and you are set.

New anchor hardware as of September 13, 2010, courtesy of ASCA.
content.location: Hike around to the south-facing side of Lincoln Creek Cliff, there is a nice boulder to hang out on right below the start of Landslide.  The routes to the left look hard and Landslide looks quite mellow in a right-facing corner start.

content.description:
This is a great route with plenty of good pro and sustained challenging climbing throughout.  Start by mantling up onto a ledge (move protected by a bolt).  Climb a steep strenuous crack with good pro and mantel again onto another sloping ledge.  Good wires protect the last crux dihedral and a final bolt protects the exit moves to the anchor.

The guidebook gives this route 12a but I didn't feel it was that difficult.  A consensus grade should narrow it down, but I felt it was somewhere around 11c/d.
content.protection: This is a mixed route with two bolts and gear to 2".  Bring some small to medium stoppers also.  2 bolt anchor.
content.location: This is the first route you see on Lincoln Creek Cliff on the far left end of the crag.

content.description: This is another long, fun 5.9 with interesting stemming moves through an overhang at the top.  Start by climbing up a short slab and dihedral and just keep following the corner till you get to a large ledge with an anchor just a little higher up to the right.
content.protection: Standard rack to 3".  2 bolt anchor with chains at the top.
content.location:
This route is located on the far right side of the crag in a large, right-facing corner.  The route,

Dad's Day Off

, is just to its left.

climbs.name: Dean's Day Off
climbs.fa: Henry Barber, Steve Shea, belayed by a young Pat Adams

content.description:
This is a historically proud ascent.... Aren't all of his routes, though? It is one of the state's classic, must-do, single pitches at the grade.

Barefoot and with only funky nuts!! Oh, and a solid wit and BIG balls!

With sticky rubber shoes, it's still a challenge, but modern gear makes it much safer, for sure.

I wish I could give it the full 4 stars it deserves. Its only blight (unless I didn't follow the FFA true line) is the rotten chimney for the 1st 1/3 of its length. Perhaps Henry followed the face to its left, but I entered the nasty (but easy) chimney.

Exit to a smooth section of slab and thin crack. Place small but good brass action, and tiptoe up a 5.11 balance crux with a slight runout. The wall steepens considerably here, and the crack widens to accept fingers. Get good gear of TCU/Alien, power up with cool layaways and jams and crimps, and don't stop till you get to the top. A two bolt rap anchor is at a distance of 35m from the ground.

The upper 2/3rds of the route is very classic and truly inspiring to know in what style it went up!!
content.protection: Brass nuts (2-4 RP type sizes), a few sm/med wired nuts, #0-3 TCU-size cams will sew up the crux headwall, a couple larger cams, and a 70m! rope.

content.description: Climb the short dihedral just below the first bolt. At the first bolt, move out onto the face.  Climb up through horizontal cracks and blank looking face sections, protecting with several small cams and a some bolts.  Eventually you intersect the arete and gain a rest before a small roof on the left.  Pull a hard move past the last bolt, and mantle to victory.
content.protection: Bolts and small cams: a single set from 0 TCU to 4 TCU should do.
content.location:
This is located to the far right on the cliff, on a slightly overhanging face just left of the

Haywire

dihedral.

climbs.name: Cramper
climbs.fa: L. Dawson, M. Kennedy, C. Landry 1974

content.description:
This is one of the best cracks I have climbed at Independence Pass.  Start by stemming up an open corner and make some strenuous moves to get into the splitter crack up above (splitter for Independence Pass at least).  Jam the crack up a right-facing corner to a large ledge with an anchor.

This crack starts out as big hands and fists and narrows down to ring locks and fingers as you near the top.
content.protection: Standard rack to 3.5" or 4".  2 bolt anchor with slings at the top.  Smaller gear can be placed where the large cams fit but is a little harder to get in.
content.location:
This is the next route right of

Honest Abe

.  Just look for the obvious crack in a right-facing corner.

content.description:
This route doesn't look very spectacular from the ground, but it's definitely worth getting on. Start in a large chimney to the left of the dihedral and climb the face on the right side of the chimney to access the corner. Stem, jam, and layback your way up the corner as it gets steeper and steeper until you reach the top. This has great climbing and is longer than it looks.

A 60m rope will just get you down if your belayer stays up in the chimney.
content.protection: A full rack to 2" and a 2 bolt anchor at the top.
content.location:
Cardo's Corner is located to the right of

Dean's Day Off

in a large, left-facing dihedral.
